This is a flexible strip of surface mount LEDs on flex (copper-coated polyimide film) backed with double-sided masking tape for the adhesive. It's currently running off AA batteries, though I plan to connect it to the extruder board in the future.

This was imaged using toner-transfer paper and a sign laminator (both from Mouser), and etched in Radio Shack PCB etchant. The film I used was a sample of Novaclad brand copper-coated film with a tie-coat (the thin layer of material that helps the copper adhere to the polyimide) that could be etched with the same chemicals used to etch the copper (ferric chloride, in this case). Not all flex substrates are alike: many must be etched in a two-stage process involving highly reactive chemicals, so be sure you know what you're getting.
After my film was etched, I tacked it onto a scrap piece of Novaclad with some tape, the Novaclad was already secured to a flat, rigid surface. I wanted a surface that would act as a heat sink because I would be soldering by hand and I didn't want the PI film to buckle or melt under the heat.
I tinned both strips of copper with a thin layer of solder and added a thick bead to the outer ring. For each LED I placed it using heavy, self-closing tweezers, then heated the solder on either side of the LED with my soldering iron to tack it into place. After that, I would solder down the other lead, then add more solder to the first lead so everything was secure. A better option would be to use solder paste and an oven (I think the film would curl on a hotplate). If you use an oven make sure your film is taped flat.
When my LEDs were in place, I soldered in two wires for leads. If you've got a narrow space to work with, you can extend the copper traces on one side and use the flexibility of Flex to your advantage by snaking the film through joints in the frame, then adding wire leads to connect your power source. A strip of Kapton tape can be placed over the traces to keep them from shorting.
When all the hot parts of the job were finished, I added double-stick masking tape to the back of the film and cut out my LED strip with scissors. Then I peeled the backer off the tape, pressed it firmly to the bottom of my Z-stage, and plugged it into a 3V power source. The result was surprisingly bright, and provides a very effective light source exactly where it's needed: right on top of the build surface. Eventually, I plan on adding more LED strips to the inside of the frame.
Some thoughts:
I'm happy with the adhesive properties of the double-sided masking tape, but a better option would be to laminate the back of the film with one of 3M's high-temperature adhesives before soldering.
Also, I etched the copper off both sides of the film for simplicity's sake, however, when I try this again, I'm going to protect the backside copper with some tape. This will leave shiny copper showing through the front of the film and would act as a reflector for the LEDs.

comments.text: Nice! I've got a 12 V strip of white LEDs mounted at the top of my bot. I like how yours conforms to the shape of the z-stage platform and that you get direct light on the printed object. It looks like you're printing out my welding gun handle! =)

description.text:
a LED light for indoor/outdoor use.
Ideal to take on a camping trip to light up the tent.

Requirements: 1 x 3D printed LED light
1 x 2 AA-battery holder (or any other sufficient 3v supply that fits)
2 x AA battery
6 x bright LED
1 x toggle switch
wiring
soldering iron
hotglue Instructions:
  • print the LED light
  • insert toggle switch and LED's
  • solder cable between the LED pins (long ones to long ones, short ones to short ones)
  • solder battery holder + to middle pin of the toggle switch
  • solder long leads wire from LED's to any other pin on the toggle switch
  • solder ground from battery holder to ground of LED's
  • position battery holder with hotglue
  • test
  • if successful : hotglue LED's in place, and cover wires.
    • Tips:
  • on the back there are 2 holes for hanging your lamp onto something, either use some wire or use cable ties to hang your light to someting.
  • even on cheap batteries, the lights last for quite some time (mine lasted for over 24 hours)
  • all parts can be found on dx.com for a few bucks

My printer is upstairs, so the vibration from the printer travels downstairs. To combat this (completely removed the issue) I designed and trialled these.  
This will work with a prusa etc, but you'll have to make/design your own mounting piece.  
UPDATE: The housings are now a tighter fit to the spring (should still be loose though). and the spring has been increased in pitch.  
UPDATE: PLA springs probably aren't the way to go, they lose their springiness over time, and would need to be reprinted.  
Thinking some of the problem could be that the orca weighs so much and is almost maxing out the spring with just it's weight. I've uploaded a taller, heavier duty spring that I'll try at some point.  
UPDATE: feet_spring2,stl is my current spring. These have done literally hundreds of hours of printing with no noticeable change. However, they don't do such a good job as the original ones, due to being more rigid.

Print springs and top piece with support, remove support, put springs on feet of orca. Bolt/Screw/Nail bases down to worktop/wooden board. Requires 4 bases, 4springs, and 4*'feet'. Note that this removes vibration, but will allow the printer to 'wobble' about, this shouldn't affect print quality, as the whole printer is moving, not individual axis's.

comments.text: Nice Idea, I use a pair of 3 x 11/2 studs and some closed cell foam mat to damp my Orca in relation to the desk and then my downstairs. Might try this though, maybe with some real die springs, not sure I would trust the printed ones for too long :)
comments.author: doommeister

comments.text: I was using vibration mat (2mats, 20mm thick each) only, while this deadened some of the vibration, most was still getting through. With springs, all of the energy is absorbed by the spring, which compresses/flexes, and stops the vibration even getting to the wooden board shown, let alone through to the floorboards.

Do you use solder ? This is a stackable solder spool holder. You can make one for each of your spools of solder, and then stack them up out of the way when you are done with them ! You will need, some 1/8" (3mm) acrylic, about 7.5" by 10" of colored, and about 3.5" x 3.5" or clear. Plus some rod. I use 5/8" wooden dowel cut a little bit shorter then 3 1/4". If you don't have a laser cutter but would like a solder spool holder, you can get the kit at SpikenzieLabs.com/catalog.
Follow the link to Lasered Items.

For detailed kit building instructions check my YouTube Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WsV3_dajtWE
  • Cut out the plastic parts on a laser cutter.
  • Glue the parts together. (Starting with the front clear piece.)
  • Cut the dowel.
  • Fit the solder spool onto the dowel and you are ready to go.

title: Superlight highres GoPro Hero 3 lens hood

description.text: When flying my DJI Phantom 2 I have noticed some issues flying in direct sunlight. The props cast a shadow on the lens that results in some banding on the video. As the camera is on a 3-axis gimbal a lens-hood needs to weigh absolutely nothing. I take no responsibility if you burn out the motors on your gimbal using this, as any weight other than the camera itself is outside the limits of the manufacturer. Having said that, this thing weighs in at 0.54 grams, before I sanded it to get a matte finish on the inside. I downloaded a file from GrabCad that I printed first, but it could be seen in frame when using superwide, and it weighed 1.12 grams (0.0395 ounces) which did seem a bit more than it needed to. After four iterations I got from 0.68 to 0.54 grams (0.0190 ounces). So once again, this should not be used by anyone on a gimbal. Should be ok on a fixed mount though. I will update this file as I test it.

Printed on Rep2, 0.2mm, 2 shells. The inside should be sanded to a matte finish to avoid reflections. Printing at 0.1mm should make sanding-time shorter.  
Update 260814 (yes, I'm european): I added the file as .Step and .Iges in case someone wants to experiment with it in some parametric app.

Print on 300g/m² paper, cut, and glue.

The Penny Silva is a 3-D printed disposable bike, styled in the fashion of the classic Penny Farthing bicycles of old, for use in the urbanised centres of towns and cities of the year 2040. The bike would be printed using natural, bio-degradable cellulose for the frame, and a bio-degradable flexible polymer for the wheels and seat (links below). The bike starts breaking down rapidly after being printed, with a maximum usable life of 1 week. After this point, the bikeâ€™s structure begins to break down and disintegrate.
The theory is that 3D printing machines will be available to every family by the year 2040. If someone wants to travel a relatively short distance, they can print off one of these bikes with flower seeds (daisy, daffodil etc) embedded into the frame of the bike during the printing process. The user then travels to the desired destination, and discards the bike when it is no longer needed. After a period of no more than a week, the entire bike begins to decompose, exposing the pre-embedded flower seeds to the elements. After watering (or rain) the seeds begin to grow, creating a natural beauty in what will undoubtedly be grey, metallic cityscapes of the year 2040.
This concept is all about contrast. The contrast between the metal, glass and concrete materials of future cites and buildings, and the natural, degradable cellulose of the bike frame coupled with the delicateness of the budding flowers. The contrast between sleek, smooth future cars and buses, powered by electricity or petrol, and the man-powered, slightly awkward looking Penny Silva bike which harks back to the very early days of bicycle design.
The Penny Silva name originated from combining the words â€œPenny Farthingâ€ and the word â€œSilvaâ€, which means â€œgrowthâ€ in Latin.
Style:
â€¢ The â€œPenny Farthingâ€ form is quite attractive and classic. The proportions of the front to the back wheel, and the large sweeping arc the frame must make to join the two are quite visually appealing. Given the time period in which these bikes were popular, this form is undeniably classic, and would provide a welcome contrast to the modern and futuristic architecture and design of the heavily urbanised cities of the year 2040.
â€¢ Unlike more conventional style of bicycle, there are minimal moving parts. This is because the pedals are directly linked to the driving wheel, meaning there are no chains, cogs or gears to contend with, all of which are possible failure points for a product which will be fully 3D printed in a rapidly bio-degradable material.
â€¢ The honeycomb shape to the wheels has two purposes. The first is so that the wheels can absorb some impact and provide a small level of comfort for the user. The second is so to provide a structure which, when the flowers bloom, will
â€¢ The frame is a nod to the style of imitation petrol tank found on some classic Schwinn bikes.
â€¢ The golden ratio was used to determine the spacing between the front and back wheels, and also the size of the rear wheel.
Features:
â€¢ Seed-impregnated cellulose is used for the frame, a natural, rapidly bio-degradable material which is 3D printed and has no ill effect on the natural environment as it degrades.
â€¢ Seed-infused flexible Polymer is used for the wheels, which, coupled with the hexagonal construction, offers the rider a degree of comfort while cycling.
â€¢ The design is very slim, meaning time spent 3D printing is minimised. The use of snap-fits means the bike is easily assembled.
â€¢ A bag hook is cut into the frame to provide somewhere for rucksacks/laptop bags to attach to while cycling.
Link for biodegradable polymer: http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/biodegradable-polymers-show-new-flexibility-2005-12-16
Link for cellulose 3D printing:
http://www.wired.com/design/2012/11/3d-printer-wood-filament/

description.text:
I have a netgear gs105 network switch, which has no fan and vents on the side.  I think it was designed to hang on a wall by its screw holes, because it overheats sitting flat.
So I built this stand to let me put it on its side while elevating it high enough to keep the vents clear.  It runs much cooler this way!  I notice the newer models netgear sells come with a stand.
This model is parametric, so if you\'ve got a different device with a different width, you can adjust it to fit.

1) Measure your device, and set the variable \"jaws\" if necessary.
2) Print two (one for front, one for back)
3) Position them carefully to not cover any vents if possible

Custom guitar pick.
Made entirely using (get ready for it):
MS Paint
Inkscape
Tinkercad
Intimidated by 3D printing? Why?! Hey, there are a lot of different ways to learn about modeling for 3D printing. You could take a programmer's approach, a graphic artist's approach, even an architect's or video game artist's approach. You might even already have experience in something that gets you an inherent step or more closer to 3D modeling for 3D printers. This model was even made starting with only a beginner's experience in MS Paint!
If you are new to 3D print modeling and want to try an exercise, try making your own version of my guitar pick with your own custom graphic, or try modeling your own guitar pick.
There are tutorials and websites online that even cater to completely new users to 3D print modeling, feel free to try different ways of designing your model using different software and techniques. If you want to recreate my entirely wonky steps, try this:
  • Open up MS Paint or a comparably crappy image editing program.
  • Create a simple unique 2-color graphic. By 2-color, I don't mean black and white shading. I mean 2 colors, shades and all. I used solid black to make an image on a solid white background. If I had added another color, we would be working with 3 colors and we don't want that for this exercise.
  • Save as .PNG.
  • Open Inkscape (free), open the .PNG you just saved. Click on the image after the default embed option, click Path, click Trace bitmap. Select color quantization and start updating the preview at 2 colors working your way up only until your image shows in the preview pane as 2 solid colors. You might have to invert the image to get your image to show in the foreground color instead of the background color. Save as an .SVG file.
  • Go to Tinkercad.com and import the .SVG. Now you can resize it, place it on objects, turn it into a negative hole space, and group it with other objects. Upload it to Thingiverse or another thing-sharing service.
    There are even easier ways to get a 3d model modeled up, but this is one way that makes it really easy to give depth to basic 2D images. If you toy around with this exercise and like it, try finding more difficult exercises using other methods. Some programs to think about:
    -Other Autocad apps in their 3D print suite
    -OpenSCAD for a programmer's approach
    -SketchUp/SketchMake
    -Matter Hackers' MatterControl
    -Blender

Build wearable DIY VR Goggles! This is great for anyone whos looking to make their own a personal display.
For camera operators and dps, this makes a better alternative to a hood over an HD monitor.
A 5' hdmi display, Arduino Micro and a 9-DOF motion sensor are housed inside a 3d printed enclosure.
The outer hood is printed in PLA and Ninjaflex, fusing two different materials making a rigid frame with a flexible hood.
A mounting bracket secures the components to a faceplate with machine screws, making this a solid construction.
Make this into a diy oculus rift by mounting a pair of aspheric lenses to the inner faceplate to split screen for stereoscopic video.
Find out how to build this project by checking out the guide on the adafruit learning system.
https://learn.adafruit.com/3d-printed-wearable-video-goggles/

description.text:
These brackets can be used to mount the Solidoodle 4 power supply to a desk, wall, or whatever. The screw holes are 5mm in diameter. The power supply can be mounted at any angle, it fits in the mount upside down or the right way up. The brackets can mount an area of maximum 77.15mm x 58.20mm.
I assume that all Solidoodle 4 printers come with the same power supply, my one is labelled "Replacement AC Adaptor" , model number "PA-1600-01". The Solidoodle 3 probably uses the same one above, check the picture and details above to be sure.
Version 1: A simple one-piece bracket design that braces the power supply in position securely (if mounted feet-to-wall) or loosely (if mounted with feet pointing away from the wall). If braced loosely, the bracket has just enough room to slide out of the bracket - should you desire to remove it.
Version 2: This design is still in progress, it is a two-piece design, allowing quick and easy removal of the power supply. Both halves of the bracket can be rotated about the screw axis, allowing the power supply to drop free.
I printed at 0.4mm layer height, PLA. Any infill will work, I would recommend 30% to 100%, depending on how strong you want it.

description.text: My wife is a long-time fan of Ender’s Game, so when the movie came out she decided to make a Dragon Army Flash Suit. Naturally, this meant she needed a gun to go with it, which is where I came in. Now you can light up the interstellar sky with your very own Flash Gun prop replica. I designed the gun in SketchUp and printed the original on a MakerBot Replicator Dualstrusion. I started out by tracing a side view picture from the movie of the gun. I took this 2D image and started adding depth and layering pieces until I had a solid block model. I took dimensions from the block model and visited SparkFun and adafruit to determine what electronics to use with the final piece. Researching parts helped me to determine that conventional batteries would not provide the power I needed in the space I had for any reasonable time period. It was time to build my first piece with a rechargeable LiPo battery. With this knowledge, I selected the remainder of the electronics I would need: two small LED rings, a single LED, several resistors and switches, a tiny arduino, and the power board. I went back to the 3D model to design in hollow spaces and access points for the electronics. With the lessons I learned from my Chitauri Scepter build, I quickly designed in spaces for all the components. I designed in a removable butt on the handle to allow quick and easy access to the piece's main power switch and recharging port. It took many iterations in SketchUp to get all the parts fitting in such a small space with room for wires to run and bend. The hardest part was ensuring the arduino had enough room for the connections. With the initial design completed, it was time to print the piece. The majority of the gun was printed from ABS, with the light-up spinner rings in translucent blue PLA, and the grip in Ninjaflex. I had printed with ABS and PLA before so I knew what to expect there. The Ninaflex was new but printed very easily. Thanks to careful designs (and redesigns), precise measurements, and generous spacing on the electronics, the first test print fit well and there were few issues. Despite my careful work, the internal space for the arduino and wires was still too small. I had to increase the depth of the chamber. This were easily solved in the first piece with careful application of a dremel. The changes were saved in the 3D model. I designed the circuitry for the piece in EagleCAD so I had a good idea of the circuit design. I used some simple test code on the arduino and built the circuit on a breadboard. With a few iterations, I had what I considered the best layout for the wires and connection points. I mimicked a bit of adafruit's NeoPixel code to give the side spinners their trailing glow effect. I made sure to leave the intensity and speed settings as variables so I could quickly adjust them and get the effect just right. Several hours later, I had the LED patterns working perfectly as well. The final product measures approximately 9.5” long, 6” tall, and 1.5” thick. It includes space for LEDs for the “spinner” rings on either side and the “emitter” at the end of the barrel (see instructions for the exact products used). I must have gotten something right, because one of the VFX artists who worked on the movie saw this Thingiverse posting and commissioned me to make one. Once he received it, he sent me the following message: “Having held the real thing, I can say that these feel and look extremely close to the original prop. The coating and weight is obviously a little different, but you really nailed the size and proportions of all of the parts, along with the spin up feeling of the LEDs. I can't believe this came out of a 3D printer.” Bonus: He was able to get it signed by about 40 of the VFX crew, in addition to Gavin Hood, the film’s director. Pretty sure my wife’s heart stopped for a few moments when she found out! Now for the technical stuff: Wiring diagram: https://bitbucket.org/GlitchTechScience/enders-game-flash-gun/src/25bb3ddf20bac30bc0c1b67eef6d2fe65bd5db1d/Schematic.png?at=master Battery casing and wiring setup: https://www.dropbox.com/s/x1u84sztj367suy/2014-06-10%2020.46.50.jpg?dl=0 Arduino code: https://bitbucket.org/GlitchTechScience/enders-game-flash-gun Printable display stand: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:797703 The model has been updated to better accommodate wiring. The new models are tagged v2. Video Don't want to build one yourself? You can buy one at Barefootsewing.com.

The control code and wiring diagram for the Flash Gun can be found on their BitBucket Page.
The following are suggested electronics. Some items, like the single LED and resistors, can be swapped out as long as you use suitable replacement items.
  • NeoPixel Ring - 12 x WS2812 5050 RGB LED with Integrated Drivers - 2 units @ $7.50 each
  • Arduino Pro Mini 328 - 5V/16MHz - 1 unit @ $9.95 each
  • Polymer Lithium Ion Battery - 1000mAh - 1 unit @ $8.95 each
  • Power Cell - LiPo Charger/Booster - 1 unit @ $19.95 each
  • SPST Sub-Mini Slide Switch - 1 unit @ $3.49 each
  • Mini Push Button Switch - 1 unit @ $0.35
  • Push Button Resistor - 1/4W 10 Kohm Resistor
  • 3mm White LED - 1 unit @ $0.74
  • LED Resistor - 1/2W 18 ohm resistor
    I used 4-40 bolts to hold it together with hexagonal stand-offs (15.5mm long) in the gun body. Each on the surface has a standard washer.
    There is also one 4-40 bolt buried in the body connected to the battery sled. It uses a standard nut to connect things.
    I will be updating the design to use 4-40 screws instead of bolts. The stand-offs have become difficult to find.

I've been testing a bit with thin shelled frame vertexes lately.
But most small ribs added alof of time for printing.
So there was no print time reduction, only in mass a bit.
For this version2, i made a pretty good compromise between weight/printtime/strength (I think)
At least for PLA that is, i just printed one at 2500mm/min (the green one in pictures).
And im amazed about the strenght.. i think it was only a little bit quicker then normal, but i did use more dense settings. But the weight reduction is 40%...
And off course alot less warping :)
Btw, Im not finished yet, so v2 is not final. PS: There is a large and small (sm) STL, because i had trouble with repsnapper v333 and the large STL. With small i mean less triangles/facets, not smaller dimensions
But maybe in other programs the large STL works fine also.

Designed for use with Faberdashery 100m coils. All parts slot together tightly. A 16mm M3 machine screw and 2x M3 nuts/1x M3 locking nut are required to attach the support structure to the holder. Any other similar nuts and bolts could also be used.

Push the screw into the hole in the centre of the three-pronged socket.
Make sure the screw is fully pushed in to the countersunk hole, it should be a tight fit for an M3 Pozi screw. The protruding end of the screw goes into the holder, spin the assembly to loosen the screw's fit if necessary. Thread two M3 nuts to the end of the screw, you may need to use needle-nosed pliers to reach into the holder, tighten as much as possible. To prevent the nuts coming loose, apply a small amount of hot glue to the nuts, where the nut and the screw meet.
Use hot glue to secure the holder to a wall, 3D printer side panel, desk, wardrobe, whatever. Alternatively use the three screw holes instead of hot glue.

description.text: This one of my character designs from last year that I finally sculpted to give away at Gigacon in DC January 12-13th, 2013. Here's the original illustration: http://garyjsmith.deviantart.com/art/Space-Frawg-286342753

The model is approx 10 cm wide as is. The one I ended up printing was 7 cm but the bigger, the better.
I printed it using the Replicator accelerated defaults (.27 layer height, 1 shell, etc) and on my first test, used .20 layer height. I couldn't get anything lower than that to turn out pretty so I wouldn't recommend giving it a try (lots of gaps in the base and front legs). I did use a raft but I'm not sure if it's necessary.
If you print this and clean up or paint it, be sure to share! I'd love to see them :)

This pass-thru protector has a channel that will receive a flat-style 3-conductor extension cord (Woods Tri-Way Cord, $10.50 at Target). This allows the cord to pass through the doorway without the danger of getting pinched between the door and the doorjamb.

Insert cord into the channel. The "inside" channel has a little bit more of an angle to help route the cable away from the door when it is fully opened.
Place it in the door way. You may optionally use double-sided tape to secure the protector to the floor, but I've found that it's fine without.
TurboCAD TCW file provided for reference.

If I had a motor with more torque it would work, but I don't. So, we're left with something that moves up and down really fast. This design is meant to house a 9v DC motor and a 9v battery. Print all 5 parts
Purchase following parts:
9V Motor (RadioShack:273-047)
9V Battery
Momentary Pushbutton NO (RadioShack:275-1547)
Drill hole in desired location for momentary pushbutton
Solder connections together
Install the "Spindle" onto the spindle of the motor
Assemble "Lever" and "Attachment Slider" to the "Spindle"
Install motor assembly, pushbutton, and attach 9V into "Motor Housing" and secure pushbutton using provided nut
Rotate "Attachment Slider" so that it fits through the "Faceplate"
Ensuring that the "Faceplate" doesn't touch the pin for the "Spindle", glue the "Faceplate" onto "Motor Housing"

description.text:
This is my take on an extruder controller mount for the MK5. It mounts your extruder controller to the right of the plastruder arch support. Originally I had mounted the controller in this position using zip ties through the bottom holes in the board, but this was a quick and dirty way in order to get the bot running. The mount is secured using the existing unused hole in the Z-stage and requires no modifications to the plastruder mount.
STL and SolidWorks 2010 model files included.
Print and secure your extruder controller using two M3x15 bolts and two M3 nuts. Place an M5 nut in the captive hole in the mount. Secure the mount to the Z-stage using an M5x14 bolt.

comments.text: I've played this game with a few of my friends and I am confused about the Royal Wizard's ability.  After I do the normal combat rolls against my target, how exactly does it kill enemies surrounding him?  Am I not supposed to roll another attack, just use my current highest attack number?  How does each unit defend, do they have to roll their respective magic defense?
comments.author: Lochemage

comments.text: Ah, yeah, this is a good question. So basically, the Wizard makes his attack roll as normal. Take the highest values available for all of the enemies and make a single roll (so if a Marauder gets assaulted and there's a Stalker and a Forest Witch nearby, you can choose the Witch's OFF and DEF values when you make your roll). You can choose values from different units, though that might only come up when the Wizard attacks units from other sets, as the only things in the Tribes that have any Magic OFF also have the highest Magic DEF values. In any case if the roll fails, the wizard captures all of those units. Oh, you can also use any of their special abilities along with the roll, and each unit affected will be contributing a re-roll as per the usual support rules.

comments.text:
So I finally made a full set of these great figures. They came out pretty well if I keep in mind that my first successfull print ever was only 1 week ago. I added a picture and even though the painting is not as good as dutchmogul's I want to post how i painted them (every Warhammer 40k player would laugh about it but nervermind):
First layer is just sprayed with black paint out of a aerosol can (try to cover everything but don't use excessive paint because it covers details).
On top of that I brushed quick with very few colour over the surface of the figures so you get the effect that you wanted. Always try to use Games Workshop Citadel Colours. They are the best!
On some parts, for expample water and hill tiles, I brushed some top parts with a very light tone (almost white) so that i looks more like a whitecap.
comments.author: Toni91

comments.text: Hey, awesome! That's pretty much my method (I use Citadel paints almost exclusively, especially for base colors) though I have a really good tip: Print in black ABS and then you can just drybrush the colors directly onto the plastic and skip the primer. Comes out really, really well.

description.text:
Large clam sea shell scanned on a Digitizer using MultiScan and the Base Plate for support while scanning (Scanning shells can be difficult if the shell is very thin... coating them with a flat paint water based paint helps achieve good results).
REFER TO INSTRUCTIONS FOR PRINTING TO ENSURE GOOD RESULTS

Import the .stl and leave the orientation as it is. Turn on both Raft and Support. This will provide adequate support to build the shell up but minimise the amount of material to be cleaned away afterwards.... at the current orientation there should only be a small amount of support behind the shell and on each side.
This prints very well on a Replicator 2 (PLA) with 3 Shells and 35% fill... this essentially makes it solid due to the thin walls.

Mount it to the bearing holder with a short m3 screw and use a long, fatter screw (M4, 6-32, etc) for the adjuster. Drill and/or tap the hole as needed for a slightly snug fit with the adjuster screw. If the screw is a little loose and wobbly, a couple of wraps with teflon tape will hold it snugly for good, repeatable actuation of the switch.
NOTE that I remounted the limit switch pcb (p/n 1042) on its holder (p/n 1008) so that the switch faces out instead of in (compare page 7 of Rigidbot manual to the picture of the switch above.)

title: Raspberry Pi B+ case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Raspberry Pi B+ case that perfectly fits the board.
 
Specificities :
• The USB/ethernet ports-side wall is thin enough to allow any connector to plug in nicely.
• The wall that protects HDMI/audio/power ports has been designed to be aligned with the audio port. Once again, this allows you to connect your devices without wondering whether the connectors are completely plugged or not.
• The µSD slot zone has been cleared to allow easy removal of the card.
• The wall next to the GPIO ports includes a hole allowing you to pass some cables.
• The case can be closed with 4 little screws attaching the Pi between the two parts of the case.
I also added some space for the screwheads in the case.
 
1000th download edition
I uploaded a new version of this thing to thank you for downloading it more than a thounsand times ;).
• The wall on the side of the μSD connector was thickened,
and redesigned to be more solid.
• I added a tiny margin between the screw holes and the PI.
• I printed this new version, it works fine. 2000 downloads
Time to release source files ;) Enjoy.
Dedicated to Nathan J.

Printed fine in PLA with 200µm precision.
You don't need any support.

title: Sticky Pod Thing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's called a "Thing", because it works with any "thing" you want to mount to your Sticky Pod, windshield, tripod or video head.  Designed to be modified to custom fit your device, this mount gives you a death grip on your phone, tablet or nav device, and it's ready to print right now.
This is a great project for people just learning to use their 3D printer.  The objects are very basic and designed to be printed on a 3D printer.  Nothing special to do, and you get to use your Sticky Pod "Thing" right off the printer.  This would be a great family project or a great way to introduce your students to the future of 3D printing.  I have printed this several times and use them in a couple different vehicles.

Sticky Pod "Thing" Phone, Nav or Tablet Mount Will it hold my cell phone? Yes, any cell phone.
Will it hold my iPad? Yes, any tablet (if your printer is large enough).
Will it hold my nav? Yes, any nav. If you have an iPhone 4, 4S or 5 with an Otterbox Defender Case installed, then you're ready to go. Just download the STL or GCode file and print. This also holds cameras, lights, microphones, monitors, hard drives or anything with a square box framework. Did you buy a specialty camera with proprietary mounts? Does your device lack any means of mounting it to anything? If so, then just print the Sticky Pod "Thing" and you will have a universal mount that works with all existing Sticky Pods, tripods and video heads. Can I modify this file for my device? Yes! Please do! Simply measure your device in millimeters, adjust the tall clip in the Google Sketchup file and print. Then come back here and tell everyone what you did. Pictures please, we love pictures. Here are some specs: Plastic: ABS - all the files associated are written with ABS properties
Mounting Thread: 1/4-20 (camera industry standard), also called 1/4 inch "coarse" thread at your local hardware store.
Mounting Bolt: 3/4 inch length "carriage bolt" using the 1/4 inch coarse thread.
Rare Earth Magnets: if you buy the Sticky Pod "Thing" kit (see link below), you get three permanent magnets that you can use in place of the bolt for a quick on/off mounting solution to your windshield. While this is not necessary, the magnets make the Sticky Pod "Thing" very easy and convenient to use.
Set Screw Stud: This is the 1 inch long screw with no head. It's not necessary unless you're going to use the Sticky Pod suction cup and it's included in the kit below. The original file is designed for a tight fit to your iPhone 4, 4S or 5 with an Otterbox Defender Case installed. This Google Sketchup file (skp) is designed to be modified for a custom fit to any device. Just select the clip components and move them to the dimensions you need for your device and print. The complete printer configuration for Slic3r (0.9.7) can be downloaded, or simply use the GCode print file on this page if you already have one of the iPhones listed above. The STL and GCode files have been cleaned and optimized for 3D printing. They may need some tweaking for your specific printer. Here at Sticky Pod, we use the Printrbot Plus. Please do not run a fan while printing these components. It's not necessary and rapid cooling may cause the tall clip to prematurely break free from your heater bed. Please download the "Thing Config.txt" file for specifics on printer settings if you're not using the Printrbot. Please be sure to calibrate before printing, then print all the parts at one time. As always, be sure to clean any stray plastic, or drill any malformed holes before driving any screws into their designated holes. The Sticky Pod "Thing" is designed to be used with the Sticky Pod suction cups, but it will work with any tripod or video head. If you want to mount your phone, tablet or nav to your windshield, or any smooth non-porous surface, then please visit our website to buy the components that this holder was designed around. http://www.stickypod.com/product/thing-hardware-kit/ You have permission to copy and distribute the images and description of the Sticky Pod "Thing" for promotion. This is a non-commercial license. Sticky Pod "Thing"s may not be printed for sale. Thank you MakerBot for a great website and your contribution to the 3D Print community! Tom Heibel
Sticky Pod
www.stickypod.com

This is a modular sunglasses holder. It uses a 1in piece of PVC pipe for internal structure for the add on modular pieces.  Just print as many sections as you need and cut a piece of PVC pipe to the length you need. The original base in the picture did not have a holder. I added it in the version that is uploaded.

description.text: This was made to simplify 5lb reel changes.  There are (4) 19mm diameter bearings with 6mm hole that fit into the flange covers.  The rods hold the bearings in a good position to feed the filament into the extruder. Using a t-slot nut and a bolt, the rods fasten tight to the 30mm x 30mm aluminum extrusions.
Press fit bearings into flange covers with a vice.  The rest is easy.

comments.text: Quick question: when you arrived at the end of the filament (spool close to be empty), do you have the problem that sometimes the filament got caught in the spool, or that the spool become so light, that you end up with the full spool falling off the holder?
comments.author: Kyoxilbuzz

comments.text: In an earlier model when I had the bearings centered over the aluminum crossbar I had the filament pulling hard on the spool.  I didn't like that so I moved the bearings towards the back so that when it come off the spool, it goes straight down into the extruder, even at the end of the spool.  I haven't had a problem since.  I did however make a super stupid move one day where I was trying to wind up a sample color around an existing spool on my printer (with an almost full 5lb reel loaded), spun it too fast and watched the 5lb reel come crashing down on the bed and my LCD control box.  The impact from the side of the reel hit directly on my SD card and split it in half.  I have never seen what 2 GB of storage looked like until that day (just a bunch of silver crisscrossed wires).  Luckily that was the only thing that was damaged, other than my pride.  So be careful when the reel is fully loaded...
comments.author: Kyoxilbuzz

new version 1.2 Feb 5th 2015

    • To Do:

I agree that it takes a while to print, but hey, you get a new little box over night.

The wall mount bracket is printed sideways for better stability. I'll add a photo soon.

For some time now I have wanted to make a Dragon / Wyrm thing and have it be hollow so smoke can pass through it for use as a pipe or part of an elaborate bong.
When I made the base for this one using a processing program to create a height map and then generate an OpenSCAD polyhedron of it, the result looked like sand dunes. This reminded me of Dune the novel series, of which I have read one book and enjoyed it fairly well.
Now I am one to go for the spice that these Dune Wyrms produce, so it is not yet determined as to whether it is printable or not. I plan to print a small one just to see if it needs any supports. At any rate, it's a work in progress so take it with a grain of salt (and some spice).

You construct the Wyrm and the Surface separately. The Wyrm is generated with an OpenSCAD file Wyrm.scad and the Surface is generated by the Processing program SurfaceMaker.pde which generates SurfaceMaker.scad that produces SurfaceMaker.stl. Of course Wyrm.scad produces Wyrm.stl, then Scene.scad combines the two stl files into a scene.
Everything is watertight and all kosher. You can modify the trig expressions in the Wyrm.scad file to change its wiggling shape and then you kind of test fit it to the sand land you randomly get from SurfaceMaker. Experimentation and trial and error is the key here. Or just use it as-is!

title: iPad Mini Lightning Dock for 2005 Prius

description.text:
I needed a way to mount my iPad Mini in my 2005 Prius, so that I could use it as a better Navigator and audio source. The products I found commercially available were annoying solutions, so I decided to make my own. It clips to the open door of the little CD storage hutch below the radio.
Included STL files are for an iPad Mini with a rubberized wrap case. This can also be used to make an iPhone5 mount.
[Update: Added speaker ports. Refactored to keep device dimensions together]

1) Tweak the settings in the OpenSCAD file to match your iPad/iPhone/case combo.
2) Compile and Render to CGAL (F6).
3) Export to STL.
4) Slice.
5) Print.

title: Inverted Stewart/Gough Platform
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: All my designs & progress available @ www.marginallyclever.com A stewart/gough platform is the machine that moves a flight simulator around. Technicaly it is a 6 degree of freedom kinematic assembly. They are also used to hold the space shuttle against the ISS and in some advanced milling machines. This model is inverted - it is upside down and hung on string or wire. Same principle, much more affordable and easy to construct. This machine is made from three Makelangelos (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26298) and a few pieces of laser cut acrylic. In this Thing I've included the DXF files for the acrylic.

• Cut three motor mounts, four edges, and one top. The measurements are in centimeters. The edge and top are both 24" on each side.
  • Screw the arduinos and steppers onto the mounts.
  • Attach the steppers to the motor shields.
  • Attach the motor shield to the arduino.
  • Secure the bobbins on the stepper shafts with set screws.
  • Wind 36" of string onto each bobbin and thread the string through the holes.
  • Slot the motor mounts into the grooves of the top plate so that the bobbins face out from the center.
  • attach the six strings to the end effector. See the 3-3 design here (http://robotics.technion.ac.il/projects/Images/ronen_robots.jpg) for reference.
  • connect 12v1a to each motor shield
  • connect USB to each arduino and your PC/laptop.
  • install arduino firmware. (not yet released.)
  • run Java code. (not yet released.)
  • rejoice!

author: JerryRobo3D

description.text: In ancient years of Yor, before the TSA and the FAA got twitchy about lasers and aircraft (Early 2000s), I had a Burning Man Project which had a GameBoy Advance controlling a Laser Turret to point out stars, planets, and satellites. I decided to see if I could 3D print a more modern Altitude-Azimuth turret. Turns out, I can. Disclaimer: POINTING LASERS IN THE AIR NOWADAYS CAN GET YOU ARRESTED. DON'T DO IT. I only post this design because I like being able to say that I've designed and built a Laser Turret. This turret should be useful as a base design for making non-laser things that need an Alt-Az turret. Maybe useful for mounting a security camera. Not useful for astro-photography, though, due to low angular resolution.

The Google SketchUp file shows the relative positions of the parts and how it assembles. I used a RAMPS controller to run the motors. I have a hacked and buggy firmware that could rough-calibrate the turret using a compass and accelerometers, but it's so buggy it's not really useful.
This design is posted as-is for entertainment purposes. I'm not maintaining this.

comments.text: This is a well thought out design. So far, it is has printed nicely and fits together well, a bit of grease and the movement is like butter. I have to second the opinion that this would be a great basis for an automated panoramic photography system.

comments.text: This device makes is designed well and the parts fit together nicely. Not only is the gear tight but its also smooth. you might have to trim a little out of the lip the gear fits into since its snug, and a little grease always helps with gears but so far I am very pleased with it. I have one tracking the X37B vehicle today at the NASA launch site. I am using this as a camera platform for the IR tracking platform. Thanks a million man for sharing this design. I might modify it some for my particular use, but the gears and all are perfect.

title: Small flying model rocket with customizable nosecones
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a small model rocket intended to use estes "tiny" (1/2 A, 1/4 A) engines. One set of fins is different than the other set of fins, in shape and size.  I have tested this rocket, and it should fly, but the nosecones requires a bit of sanding to fit. There are three types of nosecones: classic, rounded, and nearly flat. Choose whichever one best suits your taste, or experiment to see which one makes for the highest rocket launch.

Nosecone: Infill: 100 percent
Body: infill: below 25 percent
Fins: infill: below 25 percent Make sure you use lots of recovery wadding, and connect a rubber band to the nosecone and the body via plastic glue. Sand the lower 1/2 in of the body, then slip the fins over the body, and plastic glue them too.
Preferably, tie a small streamer to the middle of the rubber band to slow the rockets descent.
The rocket should be so light that it will not break upon impact with the ground. Most of all, use common sense when launching this rocket. Do not launch the rocket at someone, do not launch the rocket during an electrical storm, and launch the rocket in a field that is at least 500 feet wide.
Have Fun! Decross

A derivative of richardberwick's Personalized Snowflake (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37744) I just made the middle solid, added four posts and a top frame. You'll need richardberwick's orginal file if you want to do anything with the OpenSCAD code. A bit late... yeah. :-(
But I got all caught up having fun the past few weeks and didn't have much time. :-)

I used white ABS.  Layer height .27.   10% fill.  1 extra shell.
Drill a hole in one of the "crystal" spikes for the hook/loop/fastener.
Use the outside of the top ring to mark your picture for cutting.  Once cut, hold the picture and the top ring, making sure that the picture is in the proper orientation.  Carefully place the ring and picture down on the four "pins"... lining the pins up with the holes in the ring.  Push down and the pins and holes will act like a "hole punch".   I made the pins so they stick up through the ring too much.  This is so it can take different thicknesses of picture. Take a razor an slice off the excess pin that sticks through (or change the OpenSCAD code).

An enclsoure I made for displaying live feeds. When the feed changes it displays it on the LCD, flashes it's lights and raises it's flag!
There are plenty of potenial uses for this so use your imagination!
go nuts
http://youtu.be/Imug5Wvz9Hg

• Built for the Freetronics EtherMega and LCD/keypad kits and a 9g servo.
  • EtherMega
    http://www.freetronics.com/collections/arduino/products/ethermega-arduino-mega-2560-compatible-with-onboard-ethernet#.U-A_0mPCfW4
  • LCD
    http://www.freetronics.com/products/lcd-keypad-shield#.U-A_92PCfW4
  • 9gram servo from eBay
  • You'll also need power supply for the Arduino if you are to use the servo. I think 1-2 Amp would be fine.
  • LEDs, i used RGB ones on top
  • resistor I think I used 440 but it shouldn't matter what you use.
  • Arduino code here: https://github.com/JayMc/Arduino-feed-alert

    Build it

  • print everything duh, I used PLA on a TAZ. ABS should be fine. You probably only need 5x btn-type3 but test the others to see what works best. I print with support for the container.
  • clear holes on the top for RGB leds, if you don't want to use leds on top print with support and it should cover them
  • clean all edges with a knife and test the lid sits on top of the container and in the groove baby. Also test the servo fits nice and snug. The flag and Arduino mega will hold it in place.
  • when assembling it put the servo in first without the horn, then the arduino.
  • then solder the led wires and resistor and glue them into their holes.
  • now you have a chance to finalise the wiring before placing the top LCD shield.
  • after inserting its hard to get out as there isn't much room to wiggle the pins out.
  • now place the buttons on the LCD shield button pins and you'll have to maneuver the lid around so the buttons come through.

title: Sub Zero Mask - Full Size. Mortal Kombat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Of course, Mortal Kombat is a copyrighted product, Midway/Konami etc, this ia fan work only not for profit. I saw a low poly one on thingiverse and thought nah, this needs to be done properly...
I got a game character mesh from the sketchup warehouse someone had ripped from the game, I ripped the mask off, gave it 100 times more polys, smoothed and sculpted it in blender into a new one, gave it a flat base for printing and cleaned the eye sockets off after, all in all about a 15 minute job.
Print with Rafts, no support required, and no infill not required, just use 2 or 3 shells/walls.
Although I have not printed it yet, as you can see it slices fine and can be done completely hollow to save time and plastic.

comments.text: I have made a different MK mask, from which i used this as the base, however this is non derivative, so I have just annotated you in the summary.

title: Passive Amplifier (Megaphone) for the Galaxy S4 Armored PEPK case

description.text:
I use my phone for music at work and using it at full volume drains the battery quickly, so I designed this megaphone dock so I can play at half volume to keep my music loud and the battery full. There is a hole beneath to allow a charging cable to snake up from the rear and into the phone.
The middle section is used mainly for larger cables that don't have a flexible cable while you want to keep it charged while playing music.
On the bottom of the stand, there are two spots for magnets to be placed. I use metal carts which I place the dock on, but don't want to risk it getting jostled and falling off.
I drilled out a soda cap and glued it inside the rear pipe to allow easy attachment of the soda bottle without worrying about the threads wearing down.
